document.text: Yesterday was the 100th a n n i versary of the establishment of a U. iS. Post Office at what is bow Appo mattox, Virginia. Information secured from Nation al Archives and the Post Office De partment, Washington, D. C., tells an interesting story of a full cen tury of mail service here. There have been 20 postmaster andor acting postmaster ap pointments in the 100 years of operation and the incumbent, E. LeRoy Smith, has served longer than any other. The name of the office has been changed several times. On February 23, 1855, a fourth class post office was established here and was call ed Nebraska, Virginia. The first postmaster was Samuel D. McDear- mon. Salary amounted to 6.01. The office operated under the name of Nebraska, Virginia until September 21, 1894, when it was changed to Appomattox. However, due to confusion with the Old Ap pomattox Court House community, the ñamé of the post office here changed on January 15, 189 to West Appomattox, Virginia. It oper ated under that name until June 27, 1906, when it took the present name of Appomattox, Virginia. The office became third class in 1909 and second class in 1987. In mid-1955 it is scheduled to become first class, due to volume of busi ness. Several years ago it became first class, but reverted to second class due to a shift in parcel post business. The following is a list of post masters and their terms Samuel D. MeDearmon, February 23, 1855 Richard H, Mavin, December 31. 1855 Robert I, Boaz, October 4, 1866 Thomas E. Walton, December 22 1867k D- Hix, April 20, 1869 Willbfo l CoIKntf April 1 , i860 Mrs. Mary J. Atwood, February 10, 1666.  Ada A. Landrum, June 26, 1866 N. H. Gregory, October 30, 1867 Miss Elizftbéth H. Dee, Jániury 21, 188 Rufus Furdum, January 1, 1873 Samuel H. Coleman, July 26, 1889 John S. Plunkett, May 9, 1898 Robert Irby, May 7, 1897 Leslie F. Ferguson, May 20, 1918 Robert Irby, April 28, 1922 Lula G. Irby, Acting Postmaster. Ap ril 21, 921 Alfred R. Harwood, Acting Poet- master, May 15, 7931 Joseph E. Dinwiddle, June 1, 1982 E. LeRoy Smith, Acting Poet- master, June 1, 1034 Regular Appointment, March 8, 1936. However, this was not the first pqst. office in what is now Appomat tox County, Tie following inform ation  supplied by the National Archives and reports of the Post Office Department Appomattox County, Virginia The records show that this office was established on April 1, 1811, under the name of Floods, Buckings ham County, Virginia, with Thomas Trent the first postmaster. It is shown that the name oi the county was changed to Prince Edward on March 22, 1837, that the name of the office was changed to Clover Hill on July 7, 1837 and that the county in which the office was lo cated was changed to Appomattox sometime between September 23, 1845 and June 30, 1849. The re cords show that the name of the office was changed to Appomattox Court House on February 3, 1859 and changed to Appomattox on July 3, 1892.  It therefore appears that the his tory of a post office at what is now without a post office but known as Old Appomattox Court House, is equally interesting. That part of the county was in Buckingham when the post office was established as Floods in 1811. Later it became a part of Prince Edward and finally Appo mattox in 1845. Shortly after the burning of the court house in 1892, the court house was rebuilt at what is now the Town of Appomattox, and final ly the post office at the historic old village was discontinued. It was of ficially Appomattox Court House, Virginia, at the time Gen. Lee sur rendered to Gen. Grant. Undocumented stories often told here relate that in the gold rush days a hundred years and more ago?- some family started out for Ne braska, got this far and liked the place so much that they decided to settle here and call this Nebraska. This newspaper has no proof of that

document.text: with friends and doing some spring shopping. Mr. E. W. Gilliam, of Lynch burg, was a visitor here Sun day. Mrs. J. H. McCue returned from Bluefield, W. Va., on last Friday from a weeks visit to Mrs. O. 0. Jenkins, who has been quite ill for the past two weeks. Mr. J. W. Davis returned last week from Staunton, having spent several days with his son Prof. J. Talmage Davis, of the 8taunton Military Institute. Mrs. James Glenn, of Olive Branch, was called to the home of her father, Mr. Ben Rosser, who was reported as being quite siok on last Friday, and the many friends of Mr. Rosser are made more sad to learn of the serious accident to one of his sons,Mr. Bob Rosser, of Lynchburg, who, while rid ing a motorcycle, collided with an automobile, causing the loss of one leg, one broken arm and a severe cut on the head. Our citizens in this part of the county, on both north and south side of Appomattox river, are worked up to a point that our officials can not bring up the same old chestnut that is always politely handed to the farmer You havnot ask ed for anything, so why do you kick? And from what I have seen and heard, the citizens of this part of Clover Hill Dis trict will not be satisfied with nothing less than a good bridge across Appomattox riv er near the poi-t known as the John Marshall ford, and a com  mittee of 15 of the old straight liners has been appointed to meet with the Board of Super visors at their regular meeting and investigate further into the matter. And since your correspondent has somewhat the resemblance of Foxy Grandpa, I will say nothing as to finances. Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Harden, Miss Alice Harden and Mr Turner, of Fife, are on a visit to Mrs. Hardens mother, Mrs J. W. Harwood. Rev. Mr. Sam Harwood and wife and Mrs. Laokford, of! Jarretts, are also on a visit to Mrs. Harwood. Miss Ruth Harwood, of Hope well, spent the week-end with home people. Mr. J. R. Fore was down to Gamp Lee on Thursday.

document.text: With deepest sorrow the Womans Club of Appomattox pays tribute to the memory of one of its Organ izing and Charter Members, Bessie V. Harwood Caldwell, whose death occured on June 24th, 1955 . Public spirited to a high degree she was an unfailing worker in all good causes. Over the years every progressive movement in Church and community has owed much to her support, for Bessie V. was a leader in educational, health, recreational, and civic activities. From early youth she was a faithful and devot ed member of Liberty Baptist Church, and was a pillar of strength in its organizations and Church life. We pay tribute to her life of in spiration and accomplishments. She was devoted to her children, family, and home always loyal to her friends true to her convictions strong in her Christian faith, and optimistic in her outlook. Even unto the end her thoughts and plans were in consideration of others. In spite of her progressing ill. ness she kept up with her usual in terests with a courageous spirit. In no greater way did she exemplify her bravery than in her efforts to seek and use every known means of medical treatment, not solely for the purpose of her own recovery but also that others similiarly strick en might be helped. Though she is gone, always in our midst is she because Love makes memory eternal. Mrs. Robert C. Hubbard Mrs. Joel W. Flood Mrs. Jerry A. Burke, Chairman Resolution Committee. October 3, 1955. ltc

document.text: William Pitzer Gills, who died at his home, Locust Grove, Friday morning, was the son of James Thomas and Cornelia Terri 1 Pitzer Gills. Though jiorn in Buckingham county, he moved to Appomattox in his boyhood on account of the death of his father. He then made his home with his uncle, the late Will iam Gills, who for many years was treasurer of the the county. He at tended the first public school evei taught in this county, Judge David A. Christian being the teacher. Mr. Gills engaged in various aeti- ties until the infirmities or age made, it necessary for him to retire from, public life. He was a senool trus.et of Appomattox county also serving as clerk to the school board, man carrier on R. F. D. No. 2, employed at one time by the Norfolk and Wes tern Railway, besides managing his arm near Appomattox. He was a iason and a Woodman of the  orld, and a Democr t who was un- werving in his par loyaly. Fii nany-lyears he was a faithful dea- on of Liberty Baptist church and teacher in the Sunday School. The deceased was a man whose lie was marked by fidelity to prin- ple. His was a goodly heritage of u ture and Godliness from an an cestry distinguished in the early history of America. Those who came in con4act with him were impressed by the deep spirituality of his nature. t  The funeral took place Sunday afternoon at Liberty Baptist church The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, the pastor, and the Rev. William May- field Thompson, a former pastor, conducting the services. The choir ,f the church sang Mr. Gills favor ite hymn, Rock of Ages. Tenny sons immortal poem, Crossing the Bar, was read and played on the pipe organ as a processional. Inter ment took place in the family plot in Liberty Cemetery, that part of the service. being conducted by the Masonic order. A host of friends and acquaintances, with many beautifa floral tributes attested to the love and high regard in which Mr. Gills was held in Appomattox and through out the state. Ihe active pallbearers were A. T. Inge, C. S. McDeormon, R. L. j Burk?, A. R. Harwood, J. C David son, N R. Featherston, B. G. An derson, Luther J. Morris. Honorary pallbearers included R. B. document.text: While a number of women are lob bying for the equal suffrage bill, it is said that at the public hearing Fri day afternoon a petition, signed by many prominent women,, was present ed, urging the committee not to rec ommend the measure for passage. Bills prohibiting the manufacture or sale of other than safety matches, to tax automobiles for county road purposes, to create a department of mines, to amend tax laws, reducing assessments on the first 1,000 of household goods from 35 cents to 10 cents to amend the code, and to prescribe order of procedure In court cases, were introduced. The Senate resolution, offered - by Senator Echols, of Augusta, for the formal election of United States sena tors at noon on Tuesday, January 23, and a joint election on Wednesday, the 24th, was concurred in by the House. The Senate concurred In a House resolution to arrange a joint session for February 22, when the State of Texas will present a portrait of Gen. Sam Houston to Virginia. Democratic Floor Leader Martin Williams, of Giles county, is strenu ously opposing the proposed tax com mission bill in Its present form, averr ing that it is not fair to Giles and other southwestern counties of the State rich in mineral deposits and other natural resources. Another measure which will meet with oppo sition is the Stenbenson bill to abol-, lsh gambling. Delegate Banks, from Norfolk, says the bill will mean the death of horseracing and bookmaking at the Jamestown racstrack. The Senate and House held a joint session and unanimously elected W. D. Saunders State dairy and food com missioner, and J. Richard Wingfield member of .the State Corporation Com mission. The House concurred in the Senate resolution to do away with the pres ent system of leasing convict labor, and calling upon the joint committees on roads to consider the Governors message relative to roads and work ing convicts thereon. Bills were introduced in the House to prohibit treating in saloons to place local milk inspectors under juris diction of the State Dairy and Pure rood Commission to compel State employes to work from 9 to 5 oclock each day. The Senate concurred iu the House rneasuYe to close the hunting season at once to protect game. One bill of State-wide interest in the Senate makes it necessary to se cure a State license to carry deadly or dangerous weapons. -Senator Paul, of the Republican mi nority, is working in the interest of a measure to have at least one Repub lican on every electoral board throughout the State. The bill for a change in the city charter of Richmond for the creation of an administrative board, previously passed by the House, was passed in the Senate under a suspension of the rules, and now goes to Governor Mann for his signature. Delegate Cox, of Richmond, intro duced a resolution providing that Gov ernor Woodrow Wilson, of New Jer sey, be invited to address  joint ses sion of the legislature and of the Rich mond City Council on Thursday night, February 1, at 8 oclock. The resolu tion was unanimously passed, and when sent to the Senate was concur red in. One of the most Important bills in troduced in the House was presented by Delegate Harwood, of Richmond, providing for the amendment to the section of the code governing the state tax on corporations for the sup port of free schools, pensions and liquidation of the public debt. The present law provides a maximum fee of 600, imposed upon a company with a capital of 1,000,000, while on a company capitalized at 999,000 the tax is 199.80. It was announced in both Houses that the joint committee on roads would have a public hearing on the questions of roads and workirfe con victs thereon, according to the recom mendations of Governor Mantl, on Monday, January ?9. One of the provisions of the charter amendment bill for the city of Rich mond, which has passed both Houses of the legislature and is now in thte hands of Governor Mann for his signature, reads that the city has the right to erect and maintain, in con nection with the city prison, if the I Council so determines, a suitable  workhouse and a bouse of correction, to compel and require all able-bodied i adult prisoners confined to perform anual labor in such workhouse and to  employ all youthful prisoners in the house of correction. Many representatives of the south west section of the state were here t,o oppose any changes in the redistrict ing of the Ninth district, the Dem ocrats believing that if the district is left undisturbed they have an excel lent chance to elect a successor to Congressman Bascom Slemp, the in cumbent, in the coming November election. , .

I The Bible will be the main text book. Mr. Alwyn Howell, one of Virginias most popular solo ists and song directors will be present to teach and direct the music. He is expected to be j present and direct the music at both services Sunday, June 17th He will also organize and direct a large Junior Choir each even ing at 730. after which he will teach a class in The Books of the Bible. All Juniors are in  vited to join the choir and all young people are invited to at tend the evening class. Miss Margaret Hancock is also expect- led to sing Sunday, June 17th. I The pastors subject for Sunday  morning, June 17th, -will be the question Can a Man be Savec Instantly? and the Masons will attend the evening service in a body.

document.text: We are glad to see Mr. Crawley back at school after a short illness. . Who can tell us to whom Verta Martin has given her heart lately? Whoever it is, he has sent Verta, smiling through the air. Willie, did you have special bus iness in Gladstone over the week end, or did you just go over to see the beautiful scenery? It is rather strange that where we live affects our social ife. For example, Elizabeth lives a long way from the highway and Henry cant get there so easily, but he takes advantage of Mary Frances living near the highway. Arent you glad, Mary, that you can be easily reached? Senator Moses spoke to one of the Civics classes Tuesday on th e government of Virginia. It was very! interesting. We are all very grateful to Mr. Lusardi for making some volley i ball courts. It is wonderful to have i someone at school who takes an  interest in sports for the pupils. The Canteen will be held on Thursday night. lit is t obe spon sored by the Citizens Party. Weve missed Mrs. Harwood this week, who has been home on ac count of sickness. Some oi oui students are still at home with the flu, but many have returned,and our attendance is better than last week. Mrs. Cheatham went to Rich mond last week to an art exhibit at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts. Among the paintings was one by her daughter, Mary Frances, who is now studying at Mary Wash ington College. We hope you all will have a tHappy Easter and also that the Easter Bunny will go to you. Well see you back at school Tuesday. So - long!

document.text: Warning to property owners of this and adjoining counties, it has come to my attention from a number of sources which are re liable, that some one or com- p nv of men are covering this section seling lightning rods and making a price for the job but in some cases after the work has been done they ask nearly double the amount originally nd most of the folks have felt they should pay, and if they kick the recount is settled on the basis of the first price. I welcome all straight business deals, but this thing looks like a racket and 1 felt the property owners who do not W a r about this system should be warned to insist on de finite written contracts before the work is done. A. R. HARWOOD.

document.text: Walter G. Schnee, Director of the Studio of Interior Decorating and Homefurnishings Coordinator f or Miller A Rroads, Richmond, will speak before the Womans Club of Appomattox on Monday, February 1, at 3 P. M., at Mauds Hot Shop. The program is being presented by the American Home Department of the club. Mrs. Charles F. P. Crawley, program chairman, will present Mr. Schnee. The hostesses for the afternoon are Mrs. Otis Dewberry, Mrs. Lau rence Gilliam, Mrs. Julian Hesson. Mrs. John S. Grinels, Mrs. Charles R. Thomas and Mrs. A. R. Harwood, Jr. Mr. Schnee is a graduate of Princeton University and the Par sons School of Design in New York. He has practiced in the field of in terior decoration for the past twelve years and came to Richmond from Strawbridge and Clothier in Phila delphia. Prior to that time, he was affiliated with Lord  Taylor of New York. As director of the Studio of In terior Decoration, Mr. Schnee is in charge of correlating the efforts of the seven professional interior deco- ators who are associated with it. Their work not only includes private homes throughout several states but also commercial institutional build ings of many different types. As Homefurnishings Coordinator for the store, he is in charge of the presentation to the public of the merchandise of the many different departments within the homefurnish ings field which are represented in the store. He is directly responsible for the many exhibits and education al events which are staged on behalf of this division during the course of each year.

document.text: W. M. Thompson, Minister All services next Sunday as usual. The pastor will preach at both services on Sunday af ter which he will leave on a four weeks vacation. During lis absence he will preach at the Temple Baptist Church, Baltimore, and the Colgate University Church, Hamilton, N. Y. He will then return to Brookneal, Va, where he will conduct a two weeks revival meeting. Preaching services will be held in Liberty Church every Sunday during his ab sence except Sunday, July 28th when the preaching services will be omitted and Liberty members will attend the Me thodist revival meetings. An nouncements of supplies will be made later. The annual meeting of the Appomattox Baptist Associa tion will be held at Rice Wed nesday and Thursday, July 24 and 25. Local people who will take part on the program are Mr. R. L. Burke, who will present the report of the Ex ecutive Committee and Mr. A. R. Harwood who will present the report on Temperance and Social Service. Rev. W. M. Thompson will deliver the ad dress on Evangelism. Others expected to attend are Mr. and Mrs. W. P. Gills, Mr. and Mrs. T. A. Walton and Don Moses. The latter will present the re port on Sunday School work.

document.text: W j FRANCES H. PAULETTE Were not getting older.... were just getting better! These words could very well have been the sentiments of the jroximately 40 members and guests of the classes of 1930 said 1981 of the Appomattox High School meet- tog on Saturday evening, Aug. 1 at the Falling River Country Club.. Following dinner catered tor Maudes Restaurant, Alfred R Harwood. Jr., president Of the togse of 1980, and The Moat Intellectual according to the 1980 Hall of Fame, was in charge of activities. Frank Mutt Cawthorne, President of the dees of 1981, ud listed, in the 1981 Hall of Fume, as the Most Ambi- tious, gave the welcome. This was the first reunion for the dees of 1960 whereas the dees of 81 has bed several. Mia. Lucille CrsHe Ferrell read a poem in honor of the dass members lost in death.

document.text: W ill and Testam ent of the class was read very impres sivriy by Miss Pauline Cle ment, who iri proper legal form and as though it wias ordered by a decree of Court, seem to know how to make jokes ant facts well harmonise. Her paper was greatly compliment ed. The Orator of the evening was Alfred Tweedy who spoke on the New South. Miss Mary Beale in very tendered chords and sweet memories bid the last farewell.  , The invited speaker of the evening was Dr. D. R. Ander son, Professor of History at Richmond College. Dr. Ander son spoke very highly of the graduates this school bad sent to his institution, and declared that they considered this school one of the best preparatory schools in the State of Vir ginia. He mentioned the fact of an Appomattox boy who won the Rhodes Scholarship, W alter Durham, who won first District I Place as an Athlete at College this year, and who also was President of the Y. M. C. A. He also spoke of the fine work done by Mr. W illie W alton and Mr. Frank Harwood, all of whom are now students at his Institution. Dr. Anderson gave a most elegant speech for the occasion arid for clearness of thought, and force of argu ment could not Jto surpassed. document.text: Voters will also vote for three Justices of Peace and one Con stable in each district. You wil also vote for one Overseer Poor in each district. There will be no name on the ticket for Senator, Clerk of Court or Sheriff-these gentle men have no. opposition and have been declared the nominees of the party. Four years ago the judges election excluded 147 voters who did not answer questions to the judges satisfactorily touching their right to vote in the pri mary. There was a filed con test by A R. Harwood and A H. Clement who claimed that they were honestly elected, but the court sustained the ruling of the Committee and the judges and awarded the election to R. F. Burke and Joel W Flood. Had the 147 votes been count ed as sworn to be cast for Har wood and Clement, Harwood would have had a majority over Mr. Burke of 31 votes and Clement a majority over Mr. Flood of 53 votes. It is claimed for most of the 147 excluded voters four years ago, that they have unquestion ably purged them elves of every objection by voting the Democratic ticket at general elections for four years. Upon challenge any voter who can say that at the last general election November inwhich he or she voted they voted the Dem ocratic ticket and will support the Democratic ticket at nxt election shall be allowed to vote and no judge of election who re gards his oath of office will do anything to deprive such person of the right to vote. All persons qualified to vote in the primary, should register and cast a vote in this important election. There are more than 2300 eligible voters on the list as tax-payers, and it is expected that 2,000 of them will go to the polls on election day. With such a vote cast no man can complain of the expression rendered for or against him.

Mrs. Joe Ar rington, of Lubbock, Texas Miss Frances Earle, of Waco, Texas Mrs. Joe Early, of Corpus Christi, Texas, and Miss Mazie Gills, of Richmond. Dinner guests of Mr. and Mrs. Ernest Harwood on Tuesday even ing were Mrs. Alfred Harwood, Sr., of Appomattox Mrs. W. B. Ford, of Pamplin, and Miss Carrie Hix. Mr. Sidney Walter Brockweli, Sr., of Warwick, passed away last Sat urday morning. Surviving are his wife, Mrs. Ruth Swan Brockweli two sons, a daughter, and three grandchildren. The funeral services were1 held at Temple Baptist Church with burial in Claremont Cemetery on M6nday. Those who attended the fimeral from here were Mr. and Mrs. Henry Covington, Mr. and Mrs. Rob Martin, Anne and Louella Mrs. Jennie Young, Mrs. Edwin Fore and Rosalie.

Earle, Mrs. Flossie Erwin, and J. Sears Hix  als, Defendants The object of this suit is to sell the lands of Barbara Alice Hix and Prances Elilabeth Hix, infants, sit uated in Appomattox County, Va.
